pull.title: Do not shadow global RPC table variable (tableRPC)
pull.body:
Continues #8105.

There is (one) global RPC table - `tableRPC`. Various registration functions use the same-named argument and thus `-Wshadow` reports them as shadowing the global one:

E.g.:

```
./rpc/register.h:23:58: warning: declaration shadows a variable in the global namespace [-Wshadow]
static inline void RegisterAllCoreRPCCommands(CRPCTable &tableRPC)
                                                         ^
./rpc/server.h:163:18: note: previous declaration is here
extern CRPCTable tableRPC;
                 ^
```

As discussed on IRC, I have chosen to rename the arguments only and do no more changes.

Review of this should be pretty straight forward. Just compare binaries. View the diff in visual diff or so.

To provide tested ACK, cherrypick https://github.com/paveljanik/bitcoin/commit/5d2f98e8d1b3772f50c755e6957cb97e0dfe1e9e and compare master build log and this PR build log.

issue.title: avoid shadowing vars, and enable -Wshadow
issue.body:
I haven't looked into a fix for this, but it should be easy to implement and hopefully uncontroversial.

Relavant bug: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/8102#issuecomment-221934374

TODO:
- [x] `univalue` shadowing fix (merged, synced to our tree )
- [x] `serialize.h` and `nVersion`, `nType` collisions (~~#8468~~ #9039 )
- [x] `LOCK` inside `LOCK`shadowing (using `__COUNTER__` for `LOCK` macro) (#8472)
- [x] other misc source fixes
- [x] enabling `-Wshadow` (#8794)
- [x] document `-Wshadow` and add developer notes about it (#8794)
- [ ] `leveldb` shadowing fix ? (https://github.com/google/leveldb/pull/378, but fixed by other changes there.)
- [ ] GCC Set #8808

events.message: Do not shadow global RPC table variable (tableRPC)

comments.body: Is it required to change the prototypes as well?
In prototypes, you do not need argument names at all, so I expect the change is not needed strictly speaking (edit: I have just verified this...). I did it just for consistency.
I don't think consistency is useful here; using full names is nicer for documentation purposes.
Agree with sipa: the real solution is to eliminate the global variable, not to use a less descriptive name here.
